035 percent requires village engineers approval prior to improvement plans being submitted for review b alleys 1 alleys shall be provided in commercial business and industrial districts except that the plan commission may waive this requirement where other definite and assured provisions are made for service access such as offstreet loading unloading and parking consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed 2 alleys in residential areas shall not be permitted except where deemed necessary and on the recommendation of the plan commission 3 the width of an alley where permitted shall be 30 feet 4 alley intersections and sharp changes in alley alignment shall be avoided but where necessary corners may be cut off sufficiently to permit safe vehicular movement 5 deadend alleys shall be avoided where possible but if unavoidable they shall be provided with adequate turnaround facilities at the dead end as determined by the plan commission c easements 1 easements across lots or centered on rear or side lines shall be provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least 12 feet wide except easements dedicated solely as street light easements which may be eight feet wide 2 easements shall be designed to provide continuity from block to block 3 where a subdivision is traversed by a water course drainageway channel or stream there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage rightofway conforming substantially with the line of such water course and shall include such further width or construction or both as will be adequate for the purpose and as determined by the village engineer a minimum of ten feet shall be provided on either side of the ditch measured from the top of the bank away from the centerline of the drainageway parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith d blocks 1 the lengths widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to a provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated b zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions within the corporate limits of the village c needs for convenient access circulation control and safety of street traffic d limitations and opportunities of topography 2 block lengths shall not exceed 1500 feet or be less than 600 feet 3 pedestrian crosswalk rightofways not less than ten feet wide shall be required where deemed necessary by the plan commission to provide for pedestrian circulation or access to schools playgrounds shopping centers transportation and other community facilities 4 blocks or portions thereof intended for commercial or industrial use shall be designated as such and the plan shall show adequate offstreet areas to provide for parking loading docks and other such facilities e 1 the lot size width depth shape and orientation shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated 2 lot dimensions and areas shall conform to the requirements of the bourbonnais zoning applicable but in no case shall a lot for residential purposes in a new subdivision be less than 50 feet wide at the building line nor less than 6000 square feet in area however a residential lots where not served by public sanitary sewers and water supply shall be not less than 100 feet wide at the building line nor less than 20000 square feet in area where either public sanitary sewers or water supply is provided a lot shall be not less than 80 feet wide nor less than 10000 square feet in area or as outlined by the county health department b where unusual soil conditions or other physical factors exist which may impair the health and safety of the residents of the neighborhood in which a or the kankakee county public health department the plan commission may increase lot area requirements as may be necessary c a watercourse drainageway channel or stream shall have minimum width or depth as required to provide an adequate building site and to afford the minimum usable area required in this chapter or the bourbonnais zoning ordinance for front rear and side yards d depths and widths of lots or properties reserved or laid out for commercial business or industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for the offstreet service and parking facilities required in the bourbonnais zoning 3 corner lots for residential use shall have a minimum of ten percent extra width to permit appropriate building setback from and to permit appropriate orientation to both streets on which they abut 4 all lots shall abut on a publiclydedicated street andor an easement dedicated for a roadway 5 double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from highways or primary thoroughfares or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation a planting screen easement of at least ten feet and across which there shall be no right of access shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such highways and primary thoroughfares or other disadvantageous use 6 side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines f building setback lines building setback lines in residential areas of new subdivisions shall conform to the front yard provisions of the bourbonnais zoning except that in no case shall the building setback line be less than 25 feet from the front property line a corner lot shall maintain not less than the minimum building setback lines required on both streets on which the lot abuts g parks schools and public areas as a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision a final plat of resubdivision or of a final development plan including a planned unit development each subdivider or developer will be required to dedicate land and donate money for public park and recreational uses to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the development or a cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication or a combination of both at the option of the village in accordance with the following criteria and formulae 1 criteria for requiring park and recreational land dedication and cash payments a requirements and population ratio the ultimate population of a proposed development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for dedication the total requirement shall be ten acres of land per thousand of ultimate population in a subdivision or planned unit development plus the sum of cash per dwelling unit as outlined in appendix exhibit c appendix exhibit c is not set out herein but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the village clerk in the event the ultimate population of a subdivision or planned unit development will be less than or greater than 1000 persons the amount of land required for dedication will be determined by using the ratio of six acres per 1000 population as the determining standard see appendix exhibit c the money contribution shall be used by the village for park land acquisition park site preparation and construction equipment and other related improvement costs b location a location which will serve the entire development is most desirable in large developments these sites can be located throughout the development c retention requirements land dedication required by this chapter may include land required for drainage or retention purposes pending approval of the village engineer park board and plan commission d credit for private open spaces and recreation areas when subdividers or developers provide their own open space for private use it has the effect of reducing the demand for local public land service depending on the size of the development a portion of the park and recreation area in subdivisions or planned unit developments may at the option of the board of trustees be provided in the form of private open space in lieu of dedicated public open space the extent of same shall be determined by the board of trustees based upon the needs of the estimated population and in conformance to the total park and recreation land for the general area in general a substitution of private open space for park and recreation land will imply a substantially higher degree of improvement and the installation of recreational facilities including equipment by the developer as part of his obligation detailed plans of such areas including specifications of facilities to be installed must be approved by the board of trustees and before any credit is given for private open space areas the subdivider or developer must guarantee in form satisfactory to the board of trustees that those private open space areas will be permanently maintained for such use private swimming clubs are included in this provision when an adjustment for private open space areas is warranted it will be necessary to compute the total park and recreation land dedication that would have been required from the subdivision or planned unit development and then subtract the credit to be given 2 criteria for requiring a contribution to cash in lieu of park and recreation land where the development is small and the resulting site is too small to be practical or when the available land is inappropriate for park and recreational land use or when land for park and recreation use cannot be made contiguous to existing or proposed sites as designated by the village master plan the village upon recommendation of the board of trustees shall require the subdivider or developer to pay cash contributions in lieu of the land dedication that would have been required the cash contributions in lieu of park and recreation use shall be held in trust by the village solely for the acquisition of land for parks and recreation which will be available to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the subdivision or development or for the improvement of other existing park and recreation facilities within the village which already serve such needs it shall be the policy of the village to use its best efforts to use the cash contributions in the general area of the development for which they were contributed a fair market value the cash contributions in lieu of land shall be based on the fair market value of the acres of land in the area improved as specified herein that otherwise would have been dedicated for park and recreation purposes it has been determined that fair market value of such improved land in and surrounding the village is as follows $2500000 per acre  and the applicable figure shall be used in making any calculation herein unless the subdivider or developer files a written objection thereto with the board of trustees in the event of any such objection the subdivider or developer shall submit an appraisal showing the fair market value of such improved land in the area of in his development or other evidence thereof and a final determination of said fair market value per acre of such improved land shall be made by the board of trustees based upon such information submitted by the subdivider or developer and from other sources which may be obtained by the board of trustees the village park board or others the fair market value shall be reviewed and adjusted annually commencing one year after the adoption of this chapter the board of trustees will review fair market value annually to accurately reflect land value within the village and within the planning jurisdiction of the village in the event that the board of trustees fails to review and adjust the fair market value on an annual basis such value shall automatically increase at a rate of the assessed value of land per annum commencing on each anniversary of adoption of this chapter in any event if the board of trustees fails to review and adjust the fair market value on an annual basis such failure shall not be deemed to invalidate this chapter or any parts thereof appendix a village of bourbonnais schedule of fees per unit for park land donation or cash in lieu of land donation contribution there will be situations in subdivisions or planned unit developments when a combination of land dedication and a contribution in lieu of land are both necessary these occasions will arise when a only a portion of the land to be developed is proposed as the location for land for park and recreation use that portion of the land within the subdivision or planned unit development falling within the park and recreational use location shall be dedicated as a site as aforesaid and a cash contribution in lieu thereof shall be required for any additional land that would have been required to be dedicated b a major part of the local park and recreation land has already been acquired and only a small portion of land is needed from the subdivision or development to complete the site the small portion shall be dedicated and a cash contribution shall be required in lieu of any additional land that would have been required for dedication 4 density formula a document entitled population per unitnaperville illinois prepared by associated municipal consultants inc is attached as appendix exhibit c and incorporated herein by reference such table is generally indicative of current and shortrange projected trends in family size for new construction and shall be used in calculating the amount of required dedication of acres and land or cash contribution thereof it is recognized that population density age distribution and local conditions change over period of time  therefore the table shall be updated every two years if deemed necessary in the opinion of the board of trustees after passage of this chapter to reflect the latest table published by associated municipal consultants or any comparably reliable source if the board of trustees fails to renew said table and update same such failure shall not be deemed to invalidate this chapter or any parts thereof a subdivider or developer may file with the board of trustees a written objection to the table listed herein in the event a subdivider or developer files a written objection to such table he shall submit his own demographic study showing the estimated additional population to be generated from the subdivision or planned unit development and in that event a determination of the density formula to be used in calculating the dedication or contribution required herein shall be made by the board of trustees after review of such demographic information 5 reservation of additional land where the comprehensive plan or the designation by the village calls for a larger amount of land for park or entered into between the village and a subdivider and that agreement remains in full force and effect the provisions of that agreement shall control and this chapter shall have no force and effect provided that subdivider complies with the terms of such agreement  also if an agreement specifies a dollar amount that the subdivider is required to pay to the village then this chapter shall have no force or effect in all other cases the subdivider is required to pay fees pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and the village shall utilize the fees set forth herein to determine the scope that is equal or greater in complexity as the project each of the five projects must involve a minimum of three acres or greater of native prairie andor wetland seed installation and 3000 or completion date preplant preparation herbicide mowing raking april 15 may 1 native seed installation no earlier than one week postherbicide application may 1 june 15 live plug installation may 1 july 1 erosion control blanket installation may 1 june 15 top soil installationpreparation requirement for excavationmass grading contractor this work shall consist of the furnishing and replacing of 12 inches of topsoil in the areas proposed for planting under this contract at least 12 inches of topsoil shall be placed over all disturbed areas except areas below the safety ledge of the proposed basin and areas designated for hardscape preparation provide a natural friable topsoil of the region rich in organic matter without any material toxic to plant growth and of uniform quality free of large roots sticks hard clay weeds brush stones over one inch in maximum dimension or other litter or waste products provide topsoil containing no decomposed stone salts or alkali and not less than 15 parts per million of available nitrates three parts per million of available phosphorus 15 parts per million of potash and having a ph of not less than 60 nor more than 72 at a depth of eight inches below the surface of the field from which it is removed provide topsoil with a mechanical analysis as follows sieve percentage passing 1 inch 100 14inch 97100 no 100 4060 the topsoil shall be incorporated into the subsoil by placing half of the depth discing it in and placing the remaining depth of soil a soil rippingdecompaction process shall be utilized to achieve the acceptable soil compaction parameters soil compaction shall be measured with a penetrometer to a depth of 12 inches one measurement shall be made for every 400 square feet if readings average greater than 250 psi then the soil shall be ripped again to a depth of 12 feet using methods approved by the site supervisor all disturbed areas shall be covered with the required topsoil and meet the maximum compaction criteria prior to completion of the mass excavation seed stock requirement quality all seed installed must meet a minimum of 75 percent pls pure live seed per species as verified by independent laboratory test results test results can be no more than 12 months old contractor must provide verification of test results prior to install seed source all seed must be from a verifiable source within a 150mile radius of the project contractor must provide verification of seed source prior to install seeding installations with associated performance standards will include the following prescribed seed and plug installation this work shall consist of delivery and professional installation of preapproved and designerprescribed seeding schedules as indicated on the plans lowmaintenance fescue plan specified area denoted as low profile fescue shall be finished groomed and raked prior to seed installation so as to provide a smooth even finish grade free from debris or irregularities all standing vegetation shall be 100 percent killed by aerial cover quantified by visual observation of dead or dying plant cover via roundupr application a minimum of one week prior to installation contractor is responsible to prevent drift or overspray into neighboring areas not denoted as low profile fescue on specified plans prescribed seed mix shall be installed according to seed installation noted in plan contractor shall guarantee 80 percent aerial coverage of prescribed temporary seed crop and 20 percent aerial coverage of native permanent seeded species by the end of the first growing season october 15 contractor shall guarantee 45 percent aerial coverage of native permanent seeded species with 100 percent representation of all prescribed species by the end of the second growing season october 15 basic tall grass prairie low profile prairie or wetmesic prairie plan specified areas denoted as basic tall grass prairie low profile prairie or wetmesic prairie shall be finished graded and groomed prior to seed installation standing vegetation shall be 100 percent killed by aerial cover quantified by visual observation of dead or dying plant cover via roundupr application a minimum of one week prior to installation contractor is responsible to prevent drift overspray into nondesignated areas prescribed seed mix shall be installed according to seed installation notes provided in plan contractor is responsible to prevent drift or overspray into neighboring areas not denoted as low profile fescue on specified plans prescribed seed mix shall be installed according to seed installation noted in plan contractor shall guarantee 80 percent aerial coverage of prescribed temporary seed crop and 20 percent aerial coverage of native permanent seeded species by the end of the first growing season october 15 contractor shall guarantee 45 percent aerial coverage of native permanent seeded species with 100 percent representation of all prescribed species by the end of the second growing season october 15 plug installations pond emergent wetmesic prairie this work shall include deliver and installation of plan specified plant plugs within areas denoted on the owners planting plan areas designated for plug planting shall be 100 percent killed by aerial coverage quantified by visual observation via rodeor application a minimum of one week prior to planting all debris shall be removed prior to planting including woody debris floating at the pond edges plant plugs shall bear live healthy abovesurface growth consisting of true leaves not seed leaves upon delivery plug containers or tray compartments shall be a minimum of two and onequarter inch wide and fourandonehalfinch depth with a healthy diseasefree root stock installation of plugs in planting pods or appropriate zones based on species will be coordinated in the field with owners designer contractor is responsible and will provide for goose exclusion to prevent waterfowl herbivory of installed plugs the owner will approve the method chosen by the contractor contractor shall guarantee 70 percent survival by number of all planted plugs with 100 percent representation of all prescribed species by number by the end of the first year following installation  ii threeyear maintenance plan the objective of this management plan is to provide requirements for maintenance activities for the various native landscaping areas installed around and within the pond during the initial three years following installation once this threeyear mark has been reached and all plant assemblages have developed satisfactorily a permanent sitespecific maintenance plan will be developed lowmaintenance fescue  all fescue areas shall be inspected and policed for litter and debris prior to each mowing  mowing should occur approximately once a month to a height of four to six inches care should be taken to never remove more than onethird of the top growth fescue grasses will often produce seedheads in mid to late spring to maintain a more manicured lawnlike appearance mow at four inches when seedheads appear  fertilizer is not recommended for this turf and should be applied sparingly if used at all  once established water only during dry periods occasional thorough soakings are preferred over frequent light sprinklings  all sidewalks curb lines concrete slabs and planting bed edges shall be mechanically edged as needed to maintain a neat clean appearance approximately twice per month low visibility areas such as road shoulders outlying tree circles bed edges etc may be chemically contained but at no time will there be more than onehalf inch of visual desiccated plant growth along the contained areas  trimming shall be performed around all road signs guard posts trees shrubs utility poles and other obstacles paying special care to not damage trees and shrubs the grass to be trimmed shall not be trimmed to less than the desired height of cut determined by the mowing operation natural areas maintenance maintenance for the prairie and emergent wetland areas will be the same for the first three years due to the fact that all of these areas have closely related plant assemblages and will all consistently in the same stage of development as one another for prevention and control of particular nonnative species please refer to the attached vegetation management guidelines appendix a these guidelines detail appropriate methods of control for many of the most common offensive species maintenance for these three areas will be as follows year 1 same year as initial installation spot herbicide control trained applicators shall police entire site to identify and control aggressive nonnative and invasive species applications will be as needed and should be according to recommendations found in the attached vegetation control guidelines site mowing bushogstyle mower should be used to mow all accessible areas to a height of six inches to prevent encroachment of woody species areas too wet for mechanical equipment to access will be avoided two mowing events should occur each year  one in late mayearly june and one in early november year 2 spot herbicide control same as year 1 site mowing initial site mowing should be completed in late mayearly june if sufficient fuel load has developed to conduct a fall prescribed burn then burning should take place in lieu of the november mowing event if sufficient fuel load does not exist then site should be mowed a second time in november enhancement plantings installation of supplemental live plugs will occur in june planting will be performed by qualified contractors as defined under specifications possible supplemental reseeding by late in the growing season of year 1 an accurate assessment of the success of the initial native seeding will be possible if the plant communities are not developing to a level commensurate with the expectations of both the owner and their restoration consultant reseeding will be required the species to be reseeded will either be identical to the original species list or will be selected by a qualified restoration consultant for suitability to the most current site conditions possible prescribed burning if sufficient fuel load has developed the owner shall enlist the services of a trained and experienced prescribed burn contractor to perform a prescribed burn of the prairie and wetland areas of the site if weather conditions allow burning should take place in mid to late november if weather conditions prevent this from occurring the burn shall take place in spring of year 3 year 3 spot herbicide control same as year 1 mowing or prescribed burning same as year 2 after three years of establishment it is expected that the only activity required for prolonged health of the natural areas of the site will be prescribed burning or annual mowing in the fall prescribed burning is the ideal management technique for longterm prairie and wetland health and will be the only form of action required on three to fiveyear intervals to maintain these areas indefinitely the following species are the most likely to invade native establishment areas on the site and should be monitored should any of these appear on the site appropriate control activities should be engaged as described in appendix a vegetation management guidelines prairie habitats common burdock arctium minus smooth brome bromus inermis canada thistle cirsium arvense common teasel dipsacus sylvestrii tall sweet clover melilotus alba kentucky blue grass poa pratensis multiflora rose rosa multiflora wetmesic and emergent habitats canada thistle cirsium arvense purple loosestrife lythrum salicaria reed canary grass phalaris arundinacea common reed phragmites australis eastern cottonwood tree populus deltoides willow shrub salix spp cattail typha spp emergent habitats continued based upon observations of similar detention basin plantings during the first season following installation it is anticipated that plant survival and shoreline colonization of pond and stream emergent species will be highly successful when provided with proper hydrology and substrate conditions these plantings require virtually no maintenance activities the most critical recommended action is to control aggressive cattails which commonly invade the site immediately following initial planting cattail removal should occur according to the following procedure  the cattail stand shall be first treated in mid to late may all cattails shall be cut low to the ground a systemic herbicide shall be applied to the cut cattail stumps with a wicking applicator  for each 1000 feet  2 of cattail stand surface area treated the recommended herbicide and application rate is four and onehalf tbsp 225 fl oz aquatic glyphosate rodeo and 3 tbsp nonionic surfactant x77 or equivalent in two and onefourth gallons of water  if standing water is present cattails shall be cut as low as possible below the water line to attempt to kill the plant by suffocation herbicide shall not be applied to plants that are cut below the water line cattail plants shall not be allowed to progress beyond the early flowering stage  cattail stand maintenance shall continue first growing season as deemed necessary by the wetland consultant depending on the regrowth of the removed specimens this activity is will need to be performed most heavily in the first year some light treatment may be required during the year 2 it is anticipated that following the year 2 season the native plant communities installed in these areas will have developed sufficient densities to outcompete cattails attempting to become established if necessary the year 2 treatment will consist of wick application of standing cattails during early summer utilizing the same glyphosate mix described above iii threeyear monitoringsuccess criteria year 1 owner shall guarantee an average 80 percent aerial coverage of prescribed temporary seed crop and average 20 percent aerial coverage of native permanent seeded and plugged species by the end of the first growing season within all native planting zones year 2 owner shall guarantee an average 45 percent aerial coverage of native permanent seeded and plugged species with 90 percent by number representation of prescribed species by the end of the second growing season year 3 owner shall guarantee an average 80 percent aerial coverage of noninvasive native species throughout all native planting zones with 90 percent by number representation of all prescribed species by the end of the third growing season not more than an average ten percent aerial coverage may consist of exoticinvasive species listed in appendix a regulation of public swimming pools ch 11112  1201 et seq compliance required it shall be unlawful for any person to maintain on any property within the boundaries of the village a swimming pool for public or private use without complying with the provisions of this chapter 21 definitions the following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section fence any structure of wood metal or other material constituting a permanent obstruction to the free access to a swimming pool swimming pool any structure apparatus or excavation of a depth of more than two feet 22 fencing required a permanent fence every swimming pool shall be protected by a fence enclosure as required for residential use with a height of not less than 48 inches nor more than six feet and shall be equipped with a self closing gate and a latch b temporary fence upon excavation of any area with a depth of more than 18 inches and prior to the placement of a permanent fence as noted above the contractor andor property owner shall cause to be installed a temporary construction fence as approved by the building inspector said temporary fence shall have a height of 48 inches and shall extend around the full perimeter of the excavated site 23     112105 electrical requirements the following electrical requirements shall apply to swimming pools 1 no aerial conductors shall extend over or be installed in the immediate vicinity of a swimming pool there shall be a horizontal clearance of 15 feet from pool to aerial conductors 2 galvanized rigid conduit shall extend from a pool outlet box and shall be pitched down to provide drainage 3 outlet boxes shall be cast type with threaded hubs 4 threaded connections shall be made at boxes andor couplings pressure connectors are not acceptable 5 conductors shall be approved for wet locations 6 fixtures shall be underwriters laboratory approved for submersible use when installed within the pool 7 fixtures shall be approved for wet locations when installed closely adjacent to the pool 8 each fixture shall be grounded by means of a groundfall interrupter gfi ground fault circuit interrupter gfci or a grounding conductor which shall extend from the source cutout cabinet or distribution cabinet to each fixture all rails and diving boards shall be grounded 9 submersible lighting for swimming pools reflector pools and display fountains a the voltage shall not exceed 12 volts b step down transformers shall be used in conjunction with the lighting and shall be remotely located from the units they supply overcurrent protection shall be provided for both the primary and secondary windings c a main disconnect shall be installed on the primary feed to the transformer also the transformer shall be properly grounded 26   112105 editors note  adopted nov 21 200 deleted  314 and 315 and renumbered former  316318 as 31436 as herein set out pertained to location permit required and derived from 24 pertained to location permit fee and derived from 25 cross reference electrical regulations generally ch 9 liability of agent or tenant for violation any person in possession of mean the tax increment allocation redevelopment act 65 ilcs  5117441 et seq as amended from time to time village shall mean village of bourbonnais kankakee county illinois interested partys shall mean a any organizations active within the village b any residents of the village and c any other entity or person otherwise entitled under the act to register in a specific registry who has been registered in such registry and whose registration has not been otherwise terminated in accordance with these registration rules redevelopment project area shall mean a redevelopment project area that a is intended to qualify or has subsequently qualified as a redevelopment project area under the act and b is subject to the interested parties registry requirements of the act registration application form shall mean the form appended to these registration rules or such revised form as may be approved by the village consistent with the requirements of the act registry or registries shall mean each interested parties registry and all such registries collectively established by the village pursuant to section 1174442 of the act for the redevelopment project area exh a  a 22106 establishment of registry the village shall establish a separate interested parties registry for each redevelopment project area whether existing as of the date of the adoption of these rules or hereafter established the village shall establish a new registry whenever it has identified an area for study and possible designation as a redevelopment project area in any event the process of establishing the new registry must be completed prior to the deadline for sending any of the notices required by section 3236 of these rules or any other notices required by the act with respect to the proposed redevelopment project area exh a  b 22106 maintenance of registry the village clerk or his or her designee shall maintain the registries the registry shall include the name address and telephone number of each registered resident  and for registered organizations the name and phone number of a designated contact person exh a  c 22106 registration by residents an individual seeking to register as an interested party with respect to a redevelopment project area must complete and submit a registration application form to the village clerk such individual must also submit a copy of a current drivers license lease utility bill financial statement or such other evidence as may be acceptable to the clerk to establish the individuals current residency in the village exh a  d 22106 registration by organizations an organization seeking to register as an interested party with respect to a redevelopment project area must complete and submit a registration application form to the village clerk such organization must also submit a copy of a onepage statement describing the organizations current operations in the village exh a  e 22106 determination of eligibility all individuals and organizations whose registration application form and supporting documentation complies with these registration rules shall be registered in the applicable registry within ten business days of the village clerks receipt of all such documents if the village clerk determines that an applicants registration application form andor supporting documentation is incomplete or does not comply with these registration rules the clerk shall give written notice to the applicant specifying the defects the applicant shall be entitled to correct any defects and resubmit a new registration application form and supporting documentation exh a  f 22106 notices and availability of information upon registration interested parties shall be entitled to receive all notices required under the act including how to obtain information concerning the applicable redevelopment project area the village reserves the right to charge recipients for the cost of copies and postagedelivery charges for requested documents exh a  g 22106 renewal and termination an interested partys registration shall remain effective for a period of three years at any time after such threeyear period the village clerk shall provide written notice by regular mail to the interested party stating that such registration shall terminate unless the interested party renews such registration within 30 days of the clerks mailing of written notice to renew such registration the interested party shall within such 30day period complete and submit the same registration application form and supporting documentation then required of initial registrants in order to permit the clerk to confirm such persons residency or such organizations operations in the village the registration of all individuals and organizations whose registration application form and supporting documentation is submitted in a timely manner and complies with these regulation rules shall be renewed for an additional consecutive threeyear period if the village clerk determines that a registrants renewal registration application form andor supporting documentation is incomplete or does not comply with these registration rules the clerk shall give written notice to the registrant at the address specified in the renewal registration application form submitted specifying the defects the registrant shall be entitled to correct any defects and resubmit a new registration application form and supporting documentation within 30 days of receipt of the clerks notice if all defects are not corrected within 30 days of the interested partys receipt of the village clerks notice the interested partys registration shall be terminated any interested party whose registration is terminated shall be entitled to register again as if a firsttime applicant exh a  h 22106 amendment to registration an interested party may amend its registration by giving written notice to the village clerk by certified mail for any of the following reasons i a change in address for notice purposes  ii in the case of organizations a change in the name of the contact person  and iii a termination of registration upon receipt of such notice the clerk shall revise the applicable registry accordingly exh a  i 22106 registries available for public inspection each registry shall be available for public inspection during the villages normal business hours exh a  j 22106 notices to be sent to interested parties interested parties shall be sent the following notices as well as any other notices required under the act with respect to verylowincome households to be displaced from the redevelopment project area provided that measured from the time of creation of the redevelopment project area the total displacement of households of low or verylowincome households to be displaced from the redevelopment project area provided that measured from the time of creation of the redevelopment project area the total displacement of certified audit report e pursuant to section 7446e of the act notice of the public meeting required under the act for a proposed redevelopment project area that will result in the displacement of ten exhibit a as attached to b there exist conditions that allow the area to be designated as a redevelopment project area and to be classified as an industrial park conservation area as defined in section 117443 d of the act to wit 1 bourbonnais by virtue of being located in kankakee county is a laborsurplus municipality as defined in section 117443 e of the act and documented in the plan 2 the area includes both vacant land suitable for use as an industrial park and a conservation area is contiguous to the vacant land as documented in the plan 3 the area is currently zoned m1 or m2 industrial c the industrial park conservation area on the whole has not been subject to growth and development by private enterprise and would not be reasonably anticipated to be developed without the adoption of the redevelopment plan d the redevelopment plan and redevelopment project for the industrial park conservation area conforms to the comprehensive plan for the development of the municipality as a whole e the parcels of real property in the proposed redevelopment project area are contiguous and only those contiguous parcels of real property which will be substantially benefited by the proposed redevelopment project are included in the industrial park conservation area f the estimated date for the completion of the redevelopment project or retirement of obligations issued shall not be later than december 31 of the year in which the payment to the village treasurer as provided in subsection b of section 117448 of the act is to be made with respect to ad valorem with this article and any special conditions for discharge established by the village or regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the discharge the number type and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the village but no less than once per year the industry must supply a complete analysis of the constituents of the wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the federal state and local standards are being met the owner shall report the results of measurements and laboratory analyses to the village at such times and in such manner as prescribed by the village the owner shall bear the expense of all measurements analyses and reporting required by the village at such times as deemed necessary the village reserves the right to take measurements and samples for analysis by an outside laboratory service j all measurements tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of standard methods for the examination of water and wastewater published by the american public health association and shall be determined at the control manhole provided or upon suitable samples taken at such control manhole in the event that no special manhole has been required the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life limb and property the particular analyses involved will determine whether a 24hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken normally but not always bod and suspended solids analyses are obtained from 24hour composites of all outfalls whereas phs are determined from periodic grab samples k no statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the village and any industrial concern whereby an vi  13 11993 extension of mains a determination of who pays expense of extension the villages president and board of trustees shall first determine if an extension of a sewer main is economically feasible based on the estimated cost of the extension and the number of existing potential users that will be served by the extension if the extension is economically feasible then the village may install and pay the cost of the extension at the discretion of the president and board of trustees if the village elects not to pay the cost of extending the sewer main then the person or persons desiring sewer service shall install the extension at their own personal expense upon written consent by the president and board of trustees the village shall not pay for any extension to an undeveloped area such as a subdivision being developed unless there are sufficient existing residents or businesses to make the extension economically feasible b requirements if extension is installed by someone other than the village 1 the village must approve all plans and specifications for any extensions the engineering expense for such plans and specifications shall be the responsibility of the individuals or entities that are responsible for the proposed extension of service 2 before any extension is installed the plans and specifications must be reviewed and approved by the state of illinois environmental protection agency 3 ownership rightsofway and title must be conveyed to the village for all extensions installed by anyone other than the village the village will maintain the mains upon acceptance of the conveyance to the village 4 no extension will be permitted if in the opinion of the board of trustees the system does not have the necessary capacity to serve the proposed extension ch 1 art vii  1 2 11993  iv 3193 penalties a any person found to be violating any provision of this article except section 3520 shall be served by the village with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof the offender shall within the period of time stated in such notice permanently cease all violations the village may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any violation of any provision of this article b any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection 3523 a shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction thereof shall be fined in the amount of not less than $10000 nor more than $50000 for each violation each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense c any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the village by reason of such violation sewer service shall be sent out by the village treasurer on the first day of the month succeeding the period for which the service is billed d all bills more than 15 days old shall then be delinquent and shall be subject to a finance charge of one and onehalf percent per month on the unpaid balance e all nonsufficient fund checks received by the village shall be subject to a charge for the amount fees incurred in collecting the delinquency e disconnection of service if the sewer service fees and charges are not paid within 90 days after the rendering of the bill for sewer services the village may disconnect the property from the sewer system thereby discontinuing the service to the property before disconnecting the service the village shall notify the owner and service user on the property if not the owner in writing of their intention to disconnect the property from the sewer system the owner or the user shall be given 30 days from the date of the notice to pay the unpaid service fee and interest charges all notices sent under this provision shall be sent by certified mail or delivered by personal service to the occupant of the property or owner a property disconnected pursuant to the provisions of this article may be reconnected upon payment by cash or certified check of all outstanding charges interest and penalties and payment of all costs and fees incurred by the village in performing the disconnection as well as costs assessed any reconnection pursuant to this section must comply with all village ordinances a disconnect fee and a reconnect fee will be assessed and collected by the village in all cases no reconnection shall be made if the user is otherwise indebted to the village until such time as said indebtedness or other charges are paid in full the general pretreatment regulations footnotes  5  editors note adopted  was nonamendatory of the   hence inclusion as herein was at the discretion of the editor division 1  general provisions enactment pursuant to the requirements of title iii of the clean water act amendments 33 usc 1311 et seq and regulations promulgated thereunder the illinois environmental protection act of 1970 as amended ill rev stat 1983 ch 11112  1001 et seq and in accordance with illinois municipal et seq this article is hereby enacted by the mayor and board of trustees of the village of bourbonnais the village of bourbonnais is hereafter referred to as the publicly owned treatment works or as the potw  10289 purpose and policy this article regulates the use of sewers private wastewater disposal and the discharge of wastewater into the potw wastewater system the article sets forth uniform requirements for discharges into the wastewater collection and treatment system for the potw the objectives of this article are 1 to regulate private wastewater disposal systems  2 to prevent the introduction of pollutants into the potw wastewater system that will interfere with the operation of the potw wastewater system including interference with its use or disposal of municipal sludge  3 to prevent the introduction of pollutants into the potw wastewater system which will pass treatment works or otherwise be incompatible with such works  and 4 to improve opportunities to recycle and reclaim municipal and industrial wastewaters and sludges  10289 jurisdiction this article shall apply to the potw and to persons outside the potw who are by contract or agreement with the potw users of the potw  10289 right of revision the potw reserves the right to establish by ordinance more stringent limitations or requirements on discharges to the potw  10289 severability if any provisions paragraph word section or article of this article iv is invalidated by any court of competent jurisdiction the remaining provisions paragraphs words sections and chapters shall not be affected and shall continue in full force and effect  10289 conflict all other ordinances and parts of other ordinances inconsistent or conflicting with any part of this article are hereby repealed to the extent of such inconsistency or conflict  10289 administration except as otherwise provided herein the superintendent of the potw shall administer implement and enforce the provisions of this article  10289 secs 35683578  reserved division 2  abbreviations and definitions abbreviations the following a it shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or discharge or to cause to be deposited or discharged to any potw treatment plant any solid liquid or gaseous waste unless connection approved by the potw b it shall be unlawful to discharge wastewater without an npdes permit to any natural outlet within the potw or in any area under its jurisdiction  10289 prohibitive discharge standards a no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater foundation drainwater groundwater roof runoff surface drainage cooling waters or any other unpolluted water to any sanitary sewer b no user shall contribute or cause to be contributed directly or indirectly any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with the operation or performance of the potw or will pass potw c the following general prohibitions shall apply to all users of the potw whether or not a user is subject to national categorical pretreatment standards or any other national state or local pretreatment standards or requirements a user shall not contribute the following substances to the potw 1 any liquids solids or gases which by reason of their nature or quantity are or may be sufficient either alone or by interaction with other substances to cause fire or explosion or be injurious or hazardous in any other way to the potw or to the operation of the potw at no time shall two successive readings on a meter capable or of reading lel lower explosive limit at a point at the nearest accessible point to the potw in a sanitary sewer at the point of discharge into the potw or at any point in the potw be more than five percent nor any signal reading greater than ten percent materials for which discharge is prohibited under this subsection include but are not limited to gasoline kerosene naphtha benzene toluene xylene ethers alcohols ketones aldehydes peroxides chlorates perchlorates bromates polychlorinated biphenyls polybrominated biphenyls carbides hydrides stoddard solvents and sulfides 2 solid or viscous pollutants in amounts which will cause obstruction to the flow in the potw resulting in interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment facilities including but not limited to grease garbage with particles greater than onehalf inch in any dimension animal guts or tissues paunch manure bones hair hides or fleshings entrails whole blood feathers ashes cinders sand spent lime stone or marble dust metal glass straw shavings grass clippings rags spent grains spent hops waste paper wood plastics tar asphalt residues from refining or processing of fuel or lubricating oil mud or glass grinding or polishing wastes or tumbling and deburring stones 3 any wastewater which will cause corrosive structural damage to the potw but in no case wastewater having a ph less than 50 unless more strictly limited elsewhere in this article 4 any wastewater containing incompatible pollutants in sufficient quantity either singly or by interaction with other pollutants to injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process constitute a hazard to humans or animals cause a violation of the water quality standards of the receiving waters of the potw exceed the limitation set forth in a national categorical pretreatment standard when effective or in section 3583 of this division 3 or create a public nuisance 5 any noxious or malodorous liquids gases or solids which either singly or by interaction with other wastewaters are sufficient to create a public nuisance or hazard to life or are sufficient to prevent entry into sewers for their maintenance and repair 6 in no case shall a substance discharged to the potw cause the potw to be in noncompliance with sludge use or disposal criteria guidelines or regulations developed under section 405 of the act  any criteria guidelines or regulations affecting sludge use or disposal developed pursuant to the rcra swda the clean water act the toxic substances control act or state regulations subtitle c part 391 applicable to the sludge management method being used 7 any substance which will cause the potw to violate its npdes permit or the receiving water quality standards 8 any wastewater having a temperature at the point of discharge to the potw which will inhibit biological activity in the potw treatment plant resulting in interference  in no case shall wastewater be introduced to the potw which exceeds 40 degrees celsius 104f at the potw treatment plant 9 any pollutants including compatible pollutants released at a flow or pollutant concentration which a user knows or has reason to know will cause interference to the potw or will pass potw 10 any wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such halflife or concentration as may exceed limits established by state or federal regulations 11 any wastewater which may contain more than 100 mgl concentration of fat oil grease fog or trichlorotrifluoroethane extractable material 12 any wastewater containing bod total solids or suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such material at the sewage treatment plant  provided however that a user may be
